journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: On the dynamics of a massless beam with end mass rotating in the three-dimensional space

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Giancarlo Genta, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Politecnico di Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, 10039 Torino, Italy. Email: giancarlo.genta@polito.it

abstract.p: Many elements of machines, like shafts, blades, connecting rods, etc., are often modeled using the so-called beam theory and, when these elements rotate with respect to an inertial reference frame, this rotation can deeply affect their dynamic behavior. The position of the beam with respect to the rotation axis and the possibility that the rotation is more complicated than a simple constant-rate rotation about a fixed axis influence this effect, and different models are usually employed. As a result, different phenomena, like gyroscopic effect, centrifugal stiffening or softening, and instability due to rotation are often mentioned in reference to the different cases. The aim of this article is that of building a much simplified beam model, and to subject it to a compound, nonconstant rate rotation. Since the model can be solved in closed form, at least in several cases, a general discussion of the revant phenomena can be done to shed some light on some aspects, like the instability ranges due to rotation and to the damping of the system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The dynamic behavior of rotating beams is well known since more than half a century. The study of the dynamics of rotating shafts is even older, dating back to the end of 19th century, and one of the earliest contribution can be ascribed to De Laval, as later described by Stodola.1 The various cases, however, are dealt with using widely different models: for instance, the dynamics of the blades of turbomachines or of helicopter rotors is usually studied by assuming a constant rotation velocity and the axis of the beam is assumed to be perpendicular to the axis of rotation.2 Rotating shafts are usually modeled as beams rotating about their own axis, and also in this case the spin speed is mostly assumed to be constant. It must be, however, noted that when speaking of rotating beams the first of these two cases is implicitly referred to. Another important case is that of beam-like appendages of spinning spacecraft, whose axis can have a different orientation with respect to the rotation axis.3

A completely different case is that of robot arms: here the geometry is more complex (instead of a single beam there are usually several beams, articulated to each other) and the angular velocity cannot be assumed to be constant. Angular acceleration can be more important in determining the dynamics of the beam than the angular velocity itself.

One of the main issues of the dynamic behavior of rotating beams is the possible presence of instability or, more precisely, of speed ranges in which the behavior of the rotating system becomes unstable. It is well known4–6 that one of the causes of this unstable behavior is ‘rotating damping’, i.e. the internal damping of elements that rotate with respect to an inertial reference frame. It can be shown that while the damping of beams whose axis is parallel to the rotation axis is potentially de-stabilizing, that of beams whose axis is perpendicular to the rotation axis is not.6,7

Another cause that may trigger instability is a lack of axial symmetry of the system. This is typical of unsymmetrical rotating shafts which, while the instability range due to rotating damping extends from a certain speed on, usually give way to an instability range that is included within two values of the speed, above which the system is again stable.4,6,8
A further alleged cause of instability is the so-called ‘centrifugal softening’ effect, due directly to the rotational speed.9–11

Apart from these instability causes, there are specific de-stabilizing contributions due to some machine elements, like ball bearings, as described in Rantatalo et al.12 These specific de-stabilizing effect will, however, not be dealt here.

The aim of this article is to build a model simple enough to allow a closed form solution, to study the generic behavior of a beam that rotates in the three dimensional space, without assuming that the rotation speed is constant. The simplest lumped parameters model, in which the elasticity in concentrated in a massless beam and the mass is concentrated in a point mass located at the tip of the beam, is used, so that the equations are (relatively) simple and it is possible to discuss the results in a fairly general way. Nondimensional equations are used and the nondimensional parameters on which the behavior of the system depends are identified.
It will be shown that the above-mentioned cases of the rotating blade or the rotating shaft can be obtained as particular cases, and that the usual stability conditions can be generalized.

sec.title: Kinematics and kinetic energy
sec.p:
Consider a beam whose length is l attached at one end (point A, Figure 1(a)) to a rotating disc with radius r through a cylindrical hinge whose axis is tangential to the periphery of the disc. The beam has no mass, but a point mass m is attached to the other end B of the beam. Figure 1.
(a) Sketch of the system: a disc with radius r and a beam with length l carrying an end mass m, hinged at the periphery of the disc; (b) reference frames for the cross section of the beam.
The reference frame OXYZ is an inertial frame and its Z axis coincides with the rotation axis of the disc. The frame OX′Y′Z′ is a rotating frame attached to the disc; its rotation angle is φ.

The reference frame Axyz follows the beam in its motion; its x-axis coincides with the axis of the undeflected beam and y-axis is the axis of the cylindrical hinge connecting the beam to the disc. Angle ϑ is the rotation angle at the hinge.

The beam can undergo axial and bending deformation, with tip displacements ux, uy and uz. The usual Euler–Bernoulli assumptions are made, so that no shear deformation is considered, and axial and bending behavior are considered as uncoupled.

The position of point P in the inertial frame is thus (1)PXYZ=R1Pi+R1R2P where vectors Pi and P and the rotation matrices are (2)Pi=[r00]T, P=[l+uxuyuz]T (3)R1=[cos(ϕ)-sin(ϕ)0sin(ϕ)cos(ϕ)0001], R2=[cos(ϑ)0sin(ϑ)010-sin(ϑ)0cos(ϑ)]

The absolute velocity of point P is thus (5)VP=R·1Pi+(R·1R2+R1R·2)P+R1R2P·=+u·xR1R2ex+u·yR1R2ey+u·zR1R2ez +ϕ·R1'(Pi+R2P)+ϑ·R1R2'P where ex, ey and ez are the unit vectors of x, y and z axes and prime indicates the derivatives with respect to φ and ϑ.
By introducing the vector of the generalized coordinates X=[uxuyuzϕϑ]T the velocity can be written as (6)VP=QX· where (7)Q=[R1R2ex R1R2ey R1R2ez R1'(Pi+R2P) R1R2'P]
The kinetic energy is thus (8)T=12mX·TQTQX·=12X·TMX·

The mass matrix M = mQTQ is thus a function of the generalized coordinates. Its expression is (9)M=m[100-luy*cos(ϑ)luz*010lm24*0001-luy*sin(ϑ)-l(1+ux*)-luy*cos(ϑ)lm24*-luy*sin(ϑ)l2m44*l2m45*luz*0-l(1+ux*)l2m45*l2m55*] where (10)m24*=γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)m44*=γ2+2γ[(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)]+uy*2 +[uz*sin(ϑ)+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)]2m45*=uy*[(1+ux*)sin(ϑ)-uz*cos(ϑ)]m55*=uz*2+(1+ux*)2 and the nondimensional coordinates and the nondimensional parameter γ are defined as (11)ux*=uxl, uy*=uyl, uz*=uzl, γ=rl

sec.title: Elastic potential energy
sec.p: Assume that the beam is untwisted and its cross section has two symmetry axes, so that its shear center coincides with the center of mass and no bending-torsional coupling is present. The symmetry axes, i.e. the principal axes of elasticity η and ζ, are located at an angle β with respect to the coordinate axes y and z (Figure 1(b)).
Using the conventional beam theory, the potential energy due to the axial deformation is (12)Ua=12EAlux2=12Kxux2

The effect of the axial force Fax acting on the beam may be too large to be neglected. Its effects on bending can be taken into account by adding the potential energy due to the axial deformation to the usual expression of the bending potential energy.13 By introducing the nondimensional parameter (13)αi=lFaxEIi for i=η, ζ using the functions ηη(x) and ηζ(x) to express the deflected shape of the beam, and assuming that the deformation of the beam is small enough to resort to the usual linearizations, the expression of the potential energy is (14)U=12E∑i=η,ζIi∫0l[(∂2ηi∂x2)2+αi2l2(∂ηi∂x)2]dx
The bending deflected shape of the beam loaded by an axial force can be computed from the usual strength of material formulae14 (15)ηi(x)=uiαixl-tanh(αi)-sinh(αixl)+tanh(αil)cosh(αixl)αi-tanh(αi)
This expression can be inserted into the expression of the potential energy, obtaining (16)Ub=12{uη(l)uζ(l)}T[Kη00Kζ]{uη(l)uζ(l)}
where (17)Ki=EIil3αi3αi-tanh(αi) for i=η, ζ

By introducing the bending natural frequency of the nonrotating beam in the ζx plane (18)ωζ=3EIζml3 and ratios (19)δx=KxKζ=Al23I=13(lρ)2, δη=KηKζ=IηIζ where ρ is the radius of inertia of the cross section in the ζ direction, the stiffness of the beam can be written in the form (20)Kx=mωζ2δx, Kη=mωζ2δη3αη3αη-tanh(αη), Kζ=mωζ23αζ3αζ-tanh(αζ)

By taking into account that the generalized coordinates related to the beam deformations are measured in the direction of the y and z axes instead of η and ζ axes, the potential energy due to the beam deformation is (21)U=12XT[R3T[Kx000Kη000Kζ]R303×202×302×2]X where (22)R3=[1000cos(β)sin(β)0-sin(β)cos(β)]
The stiffness matrix depends thus on the generalized coordinates and velocities through αi, on the nondimensional parameters γ, δn and δx and on angle β, expressing the characteristics of the system.

A simplified expression of the stiffness can be obtained by substituting the expression of the deflected shapes of the beam ηi(x) obtained from equation (15) with the simpler expression typical of a beam with no axial force. Operating in this way, the following expressions of the bending stiffness are obtained (23)Kη≈mωζ2δη(1+25αη2), Kζ≈mωζ2(1+25αζ2)
The same expression can be obtained from equation (17) by expressing the hyperbolic tangent in Taylor series and truncating it after the third term.

The final expression of the stiffness matrix is thus (24)K=mωη2[[Kx*000Ky*Kyz*0Kyz*Kz*]03×203×202×2] where (25)Kx*=δx (26)Ky*=13[δηαη3αη-tanh(αη)cos2(β)+αζ3αζ-tanh(αζ)sin2(β)] (27)Kxy*=13[δηαη3αη-tanh(αη)-αζ3αζ-tanh(αζ)]sin(β)cos(β) (28)Kz*=13[δηαη3αη-tanh(αη)sin2(β)+αζ3αζ-tanh(αζ)cos2(β)]

sec.title: Gravitational potential energy
sec.p: Assume that the system lies within a constant gravitational field characterized by the accelerations gx, gy and gz, directed along the (positive) axes of the inertial frames. Any position of the system in a gravitational field can be thus accounted for; if the Z-axis is vertical and directed upwards, for instance, gx = gy = 0, and gz = −g. A gravitational potential energy can be defined as (29)Ug=-mg[gxgygz]T(R1Pi+R1R2P)

By introducing the nondimensional gravitational accelerations (30)gi*=gilωζ2 where i=x,y,z with simple computations it follows that (31)[sgn(s)·]a={sgn(s), s≥π2kks·cos(ks), ▵s≤π2k}. (32)+[-gx*sin(ϕ)+gy*cos(ϕ)]uy* +gz*[uz*cos(ϑ)-(1+ux*)sin(ϑ)]}

sec.title: Dissipation function
sec.p: Damping plays an important role in the stability of rotating systems, so it will be introduced into the model, although in a very simple form. A viscous rotating damping is assumed, leading to a Raleigh dissipation function (33)Fr=12X·T[R3T[cx000cη000cζ]R303×202×302×2]X·=12X·TCrX·

By introducing the damping ratios (34)ζη=χηζ=cη2mωζδη, ζ=cζ2mωζ,ζx=χxζ=cx2mωζδx the rotating damping matrix is (35)Cr=mωζ[[Cx*000Cy*Cyz*0Cyz*Cz*]03×202×302×2] where (36)Cx*=2ζχxδx (37)C11*=2ζ[χηδηcos2(β)+sin2(β)] (38)C12*=2ζ(χηδη-1)cos(β)sin(β) (39)C22*=2ζ[χηδηsin2(β)+χδcos2(β)]

The definition of a suitable nonrotating damping is more difficult and depends on the characteristics of the actual system to be modeled. Here a simplified viscous damping having a dissipation function (40)Fn=12cnVpTVp=12cnX·TQTQX· is assumed. The nonrotating damping matrix is thus (41)Cn=cnmM=2ζψωnM where the nonrotating damping ratio is (42)ζn=ζψ=cn2mωζ and ψ = ζn/ζ is the ratio between the nonrotating and the rotating damping.

sec.title: Virtual work
sec.p: The generalized forces applied to the system are the driving torques applied to the beam, causing it to move in ϕ and ϑ direction.
The virtual work due to the driving torques M1 and M2 is (43)δL=M1δϕ+M2δϑ

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: To simplify the expressions of the equations of motion, they will be written in a nondimensional form. It is possible to define a nondimensional time by multiplying it by ωη: τ = tωη. The derivatives with respect to the nondimensional time are thus (44)φ'=φ·ωη, φ''=φ··ωη2
Moments are made nondimensional by dividing by ml2ωζ2 (45)M1*=M1ml2ωζ2, M2*=M2ml2ωζ2

The equations of motion can be obtained directly from Lagrange equations. By taking into account that the mass matrix is a function of the generalized coordinates, the nondimensional equations of motion it can be written in the form (46)M*X*'=f(X*)+u* where (47)X*=[uy*uy*uy*ϕϑ]T (48)u*=[000M1*M2*]T (49)M*=[100-uy*cos(ϑ)uz*010m24*0001-uy*sin(ϑ)-(1+ux*)-uy*cos(ϑ)m24*-uy*sin(ϑ)m44*m45*uz*0-(1+ux*)m45*m55*] (50)f1=2ϕ'uy*'cos(ϑ)-2ϑ'uz*'+ϕ'2m24*cos(ϑ)+ϑ'2(1+ux*)+ -Cx*ux*'-2ζψux*'+2ζψuy*cos(ϑ)ϕ'-2ζψuz*ϑ'-Kx*ux*+ -12{∂Kη*∂ux*[uy*cos(β)+uz*sin(β)]2+∂Kζ*∂ux*[uy*sin(β)+uz*cos(β)]2} +[gx*cos(ϕ)+gy*sin(ϕ)]cos(ϑ)-gz*sin(ϕ) (51)f2=-2ϕ'ux*'cos(ϑ)-2sin(ϑ)uz*'ϕ'+uy*ϕ'2+2m1*ϑ'ϕ'+ -C11*uy*'-C12*uz*'-2ζψuy*'-2ζψm24*ϕ'-K11*uy*-K12*uz*+ -gx*sin(ϕ)+gy*cos(ϕ) (52)f3=2ϑ'ux*'+2sin(ϑ)uy*'ϕ'+uz*ϑ'2+sin(ϑ)m24*ϕ'2-C12*uy*'-C22*uz*'+ -2ζψuz*'+2ζψuy*sin(ϑ)ϕ'+2ζψ(1+ux*)ϑ'-K12*uy*-K22*uz*+ -12{∂Kη*∂uz*[uy*cos(β)+uz*sin(β)]2+∂Kζ*∂uz*[uy*sin(β)+uz*cos(β)]2} +[gx*cos(ϕ)+gy*sin(ϕ)]sin(ϑ)+gz*cos(ϑ) (53)f4=-2cos(ϑ)m24*ux*'ϕ'-2uy*uy*'ϕ'-2sin(ϑ)m24*uz*'ϕ'-2uy*sin(ϑ)ux*'ϑ' +2uy*cos(ϑ)uz*'ϑ'-uy*m3*ϑ'2+2m2*ϑ'ϕ'+2ζrψuy*cos(ϑ)ux*'+ -2ζrψm24*uy*'+2ζψuy*sin(ϑ)uz*'-2ζψm44*ϕ'-2ζψm45*ϑ' +[-gx*sin(ϕ)+gy*cos(ϕ)](γ+m3*)-[gx*cos(ϕ)+gy*sin(ϕ)]uy* (54)f5=-2m1*uy*'ϕ'-2uz*'ϑ'uz*-m2*ϕ'2-2ϑ'ux*'(1+ux*)+ -12{∂Kη*∂ϑ[uy*cos(β)+uz*sin(β)]2+∂Kζ*∂ϑ[uy*sin(β)+uz*cos(β)]2}-2ζψux*' +2ζψ(1+ux*)uz*'-2ζψm45*ϕ'-2ζψm55*ϑ'-gz*m3*-[gx*cos(ϕ)+gy*sin(ϕ)]m1* m24*, m44*, m45* and m55* are expressed by equation (10), and (55)m1*=(1+ux*)sin(ϑ)-uz*cos(ϑ) (56)m2*=12[(1+ux*)2-uz*2]sin(2ϑ) +γm1*-uz*(1+ux*)cos(2ϑ) (57)m3*=(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)

The axial force Fax due to centrifugal forces can be approximated by introducing constant angular speeds ϑ′ and φ′ in the first equation of motion, where all accelerations and all the other velocities are set to zero and the gravitational acceleration is neglected. The nondimensional value of the force Fax*=Faxmlωζ2 is thus (58)Fax*=ϕ'2[γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)]cos(ϑ) +ϑ'2(1+ux*)
The derivatives of the stiffness can be easily computed (59){∂Ki*∂Xj=∂Ki*∂αi∂αi∂Fax*∂Fax*∂Xj where i=η,ζ and Xj=ux*,uz*,ϑ∂Ki*∂Xj=0where i=η,ζ and Xj=uy*,ϕ
Since (60)αη=3δηFax* αζ=3Fax* the derivatives with respect to Fax* are (61)∂Kη*∂Fax*=αi3αi-3tanh(αi)-αηtanh2(αi)2δη[αi-tanh(αi)]2 (62)∂Kζ*∂Fax*=αi3αi-3tanh(αi)-αηtanh2(αi)2[αi-tanh(αi)]2
The derivatives of the axial force are (63)∂Fax*∂ux*=ϕ'2cos2(ϑ)+ϑ'2∂Fax*∂uz*=ϕ'2sin(ϑ)cos(ϑ)∂Fax*∂φ=-ϕ'2{sin(ϑ)[γ+2(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)] -uz*[cos2(ϑ)-sin2(ϑ)]}

The nondimensional dynamics of the system depends only on 8 parameters: β, γ, δx, δη, ζ, χx, χη, ψ plus the nondimensional gravitational accelerations gx*, gy* and gz*. To pass from the nondimensional dynamics to the actual dynamics, the following characteristics of the system must be stated: m, l and product EIη.

sec.title: Beam rotating at constant speed about the Z-axis
sec.p: In this case ϕ·=Ω (or its nondimensional value, obtained by dividing it by ωη, φ′ = Ω*) and ϑ are constant (hence ϕ··=ϑ·=ϑ··=0) and usually the gravitational acceleration is neglected, since it is small when compared with the centrifugal acceleration. The first three equations of motion reduce to (64)Ix··+(2Ω*G+2ζψI+R3TCR3)x·+(-Ω*2KΩ+2ζψΩ*G+R3TKR3)x+F1=F2 where (65)x=[uy*uy*uy*]T (66)G=[0-cos(ϑ)0cos(ϑ)0sin(ϑ)0-sin(ϑ)0] (67)C=2ζ[χxδx000χηδη0001] (68)KΩ=[cos2(ϑ)0sin(ϑ)cos(ϑ)010sin(ϑ)cos(ϑ)0sin2(ϑ)] (69)K=[δx000Kη*000Kζ*] (70)F1=12{∂Kη*∂ux*[uy*cos(β)+uz*sin(β)]2+∂Kζ*∂ux*[uy*sin(β)+uz*cos(β)]20∂Kη*∂uz*[uy*cos(β)+uz*sin(β)]2+∂Kζ*∂uz*[uy*sin(β)+uz*cos(β)]2} (71)F2={Ω*2[γ+cos(ϑ)]cos(ϑ)-2Ω*ζψ[γ+cos(ϑ)]Ω*2sin(ϑ)[γ+cos(ϑ)]}
Two further equations allowing to compute the driving torques to be applied to the beam to keep the spin speed Ω and angle ϑ constant can be obtained from the other two equations of motion.

The equations of motion are nonlinear in the variables of motion ux*, uy* and uz*, owing to the presence of vector F1 and, above all, to the fact that the stiffness depends on the axial force that, in turns, depend on the displacements. A linearized solution can be easily obtained, by separating a static solution from the dynamic one, which is only an approximation owing to the nonlinear nature of the problem. The static solution can be obtained by setting to zero the velocities x· and the acceleration x··, obtaining (72)x=(-Ω*2KΩ+2ζψΩ*G+R3TKR3)-1(F2-F1)

By analyzing the structure of the matrices and the vectors involved, it is clear that in case β = 0 (axes y and z are principal axes of elasticity of the beam) and there is no nonrotating damping, the problem uncouples: the axial and out-of-plane bending behavior does not contain the displacement uy''* and can be solved separately. Displacement uy* is equal to zero, and (73){ux*uz*}={-Ω*2[cos2(ϑ)sin(ϑ)cos(ϑ)sin(ϑ)cos(ϑ)sin2(ϑ)] +[δx00Kζ*]}-1(Ω*2(γ+cos(ϑ)){cos(ϑ)sin(ϑ)}-Fr1) where the ‘reduced’ vector Fr1 is obtained from the full vector by cancelling its second row.

Once the static values of ux* and uz* are obtained (from the nonlinear uncoupled problem if it is the case, or the nonlinear coupled one), it is possible to compute the axial force Fax (and hence the bending stiffness of the beam) and to proceed to the study of the linearized dynamics of the system, by neglecting vector F1 and keeping the stiffness constant. This is possible if the dynamic component of the displacement is small, while the static one can be larger, even if within the limits of the beam theory.

The nondimensional displacements in the zx plane for an undamped beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δx = 2500 and δη = 0.5 is plotted as a function of angle ϑ for various values of the speed in Figure 2. As expected, the axial displacement is much smaller than the bending displacement, and the inextensional theory could be used. Figure 2.
Nondimensional static displacement for an undamped beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δx = 2500 and δη = 2 as a function of angle ϑ for various values of the nondimensional speed.

In the figure both the solutions obtained by considering and neglecting vector F1 are reported and the effect of the latter is shown to be quite small. On the contrary, the effect of the nonlinearities is not small.

The high bending and possibly axial stressing of the beam requires that either the beam is close to be radial (ϑ close to 0) or axial (ϑ close to 90° and γ = 0) with respect to the rotation axis of the system, or the speed is small.

Since the angular velocity ϑ′ is equal to zero, the nondimensional axial force reduces to (74)Fax*=ϕ'2[γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)]cos(ϑ) and the bending moment in the xz plane is (75)Mb=ml2ωζ2Fax*tan(ϑ)=ml2ωζ2ϕ'2 [γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)]sin(ϑ)

If β ≠ 0 the beam bends in a plane that is neither xz nor xζ plane, so the computation of the stress must be done taking this into account. If β = 0 the maximum stress acting on the beam, taking into account both bending and normal stress is (76)σmax=MbyI+FaxA where y is the distance of the most stressed point from y axis; if the y axis is a symmetry axis for the cross section it is half the thickness of the beam.
With simple computation, it is possible to write (77)σmax=Eϕ'2[γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)] [3ylsin(ϑ)+1δxcos(ϑ)]
The maximum nondimensional speed that can be reached, at which the allowable strength σa of the material is reached, is (78)ϕmax'=σaE1[γ+(1+ux*)cos(ϑ)+uz*sin(ϑ)][3ylsin(ϑ)+1δxcos(ϑ)]

This limitation for the beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δx = 2500 and δη = 2 (Figure 2), y/l = 1/δx=0.02 (rectangular cross section) and σa/E = 0.005 is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Maximum value of the nondimensional speed as a function of the angle φ. Undamped beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δx = 2500, δη = 2, .y/l = 0.02 and σa/E = 0.005.

If angle ϑ is small, the linearized solution is very close to the fully nonlinear one. The two approaches diverge only at high values of ϑ and, when ϑ → 90° the critical speed is the limiting value of the speed. This could be easily expected, since when ϑ = 90° and γ = 0 the system becomes an asymmetrical Jeffcott rotor, that has an instability range starting from the lowest critical speed Ω* = 1, if the speeds and frequencies are normalized with respect to the lowest natural frequency). In case of the linearized model, the loads are located on the undeflected system, and the rotor can spin at an arbitrarily high speed. In the nonlinear model, the deformation is accounted for, and since it tends to infinity at the critical speed (instability) also the stresses tend to infinity. Beyond the instbility range, there is another region of possible working, but this cannot be found by the algorithm here used for solving the nonlinear equation.
At any rate, the speed limitation is very severe in the whole range of ϑ , except for ϑ → 0.

Once that the static solution has been obtained, and with it also the values of the stiffness, there is no difficulty in studying the linearized dynamics of the system using the homogeneous equation (64). det[s*2+s*2ζ(ψ+χηδη)+δη-Ω*22Ω*(s*+ζψ)-2Ω*(s*+ζψ)s*2+s*2ζ(ψ+1)+1-Ω*2]=0

sec.title: The Jeffcott rotor: Case with γ = 0 and θ = 90°
sec.p: If vector F1 is neglected, the first equation uncouples from the other two. By stating ϑ = 90° and γ = 0, premultiplying the equation by R3 and postmultiplying it by R3T, it follows (79)ux''*+2ζ(χxδx+ψ)ux'*+δxux*=0, [1001]{uy''*uz''*}+[2ζ(ψ+χηδη)2Ω*-2Ω*2ζ(ψ+1)]{uy'*uz'*} (80)+[δη-Ω*22ζψΩ*-2ζψΩ*1-Ω*2]{uy*uz*}=0
Equation (79) is the usual equation for a mass-spring-system with a single degree of freedom, and describes the axial dynamic behavior of a Jeffcott rotor.

Equation (80) coincides with the equation of motion for the lateral behavior of an unsymmetrical jeffcott rotor written in the rotating coordinates, reported in Genta.6 Angle β thus does not appear in the equation and the only parameters that affect the behavior of the system are δη, ζ, χη and ψ, apart from the nondimensional spin speed Ω*. This is equivalent to measuring the rotation angle φ with respect to the principal axys of elasticity η instead of the hinge axis y.
The characteristic equation of the system, written in terms of the nondimensional Laplace variable s* is

The case with δη = 2, ζ = 0.2, χη = 2 and ψ = 0.8 and the corresponding undamped case (δη = 2, ζ = 0, χ and ψ being immaterial) are studied in Figure 4, where the whirl speed in the inertial frame ℑ(s*) + Ω* and the decay rate ℜ(s*) are reported as functions of spin speed Ω*. As it is well known, two causes of instability (in the plot, denoted by ℜ(s*) > 0) are present: the asymmetry of the rotor, that cause an instability range that in the undamped system spans between Ω* = 1 and Ω*=δ, and rotating damping that in the symmetric rotor cause a instability region starting at the threshold of instability Ω* = 1 + ψ. These effects are widely discussed in rotordynamics and will not be dealt with further. Figure 4.
Asymmetric Jeffcott rotor with δη = 2: whirl speed in the inertial frame ℑ(s*) + Ω* and decay rate ℜ (s*) as functions of spin speed Ω*.
The two equations yielding the driving torques to be applied to the beam to keep the spin speed ϕ· and angle ϑ constant will not be discussed.

sec.title: Radial (θ = 0) rotating beam
sec.p: Again, the solution can be obtained by solving the nonlinear static displacements, and then the linearized homogenous equation associated to equation (81).

In this case no uncoupling is theoretically possible between axial and bending vibration, but the frequencies are much separated and thus the coupling is so weak that it can be neglected in an approximate way. This uncoupling is usually referred to as the ‘inextensional theory’ for rotating beams (and rings).

If β = 0 the in-plane (in xy-plane) and out-of-plane (in xz-plane) vibrations (that are weakly coupled with the axial vibrations) uncouple, while if β ≠ 0 the vibration occurs in planes inclined with respect to the coordinate planes of frame xyz.

In the uncoupled dynamics, the circulatory matrix (the skew-symmetric part of the stiffness matrix) vanishes and the stiffness matrix is positive defined (Kη* is larger than Ω*2) and consequently no instability is possible. The fact that in the case of rotating blades the rotating damping does not cause instability has already been demonstrated.6,7 No centrifugal softening is also present, except for a very weak softening in the axial behavior, as already shown in Genta and Silvagni.11

An example related with the case with β = 0, δx = 300, δη = 0.5, ζ = 0.2, χx = χη = 1, ψ = 0.8 and various values of γ is shown in Figure 5. The value of δx is high enough to guarantee a good (although not exact) axial-bending uncoupling (the lines related to the coupled and uncoupled behavior are superimposed in Figure 3). Its value comes from assuming a slenderness of the beam equal to 30, referred to the η axis, quite a low value for an Euler–Bernoulli beam. The values of s for both models at the maximum speed considered are reported in Table 1. Figure 5.
Natural frequencies (in the rotating frame) and decay rate of the bending modes of a radial rotating beam spinning at constant speed. β = 0, δx = 300, δη = 0.5, ζ = 0.2, χx = χη = 2, ψ = 0.8 and various values of γ(γ = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 0.9). Both the coupled and uncoupled solution is shown.
Table 1.
Nondimensional natural frequencies and decay rates of the models studied in Figure 5 with γ = 0 at the speed Ω* = 2.
Coupled Damped Coupled Undamped Uncoupled Damped Uncoupled Undamped
−0.222±2.248i ±2.259i −0.220±2.232i ±2.243i
−0.161±3.114i ±3.119i −0.161±3.114i ±3.119i
−3.482±16.727i ±17.086i – –

sec.title: Beam at a general angle ϑ
sec.p: The two limiting cases (ϑ = 0 and ϑ = 90°) yield quite different results: in the first there is no instability while in the second case two kinds of instability ranges are present: that due to anisotropy and that due to rotating damping. It is reasonable to expect that there is a gradual passage from one type of behavior to the other for intermediate values of ϑ. It must also be stated that in the intermediate cases there is a static bending of the beam due to centrifugal forces (first element of the vector at right hand side in equation (64)) and this static load limits the maximum speed the beam can withstand. The present work is based on the beam theory, that assumes small displacements. As a consequence, the results are increasingly questionable when the tip displacement reaches values that are not much smaller than the length of the beam (uz* <<1) and in Figure 2 the curves are interrupted when the larger displacement reaches a value of 0.6. As already stated, this and the high bending stressing of the beam, require that either the beam is close to be radial (ϑ close to 0) or axial (ϑ close to 90° and γ = 0) or the speed is small.

The dynamics can be studied using the homogeneous equation associated to equation (64). Since the equation is linear, the natural frequencies and the decay rates can be computed through the usual procedures. Typical results for a beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δx = 300, δη = 0.5, ζ = 0.2, ψ = 0.8 and χx = χη = 2 are plotted in Figure 6, both for the damped and the undamped system. The figure has, however, been obtained computing the static deflections from a linearized form of the equation (73) and extends up to values of the speed in which the beam theory is very questionable. Actually, only the part of the plot extending below Ω* ≈ 0.8–1.2 is physically meaningful; the part on the right of each subplot is reported only to show what is the situation in the case the nonlinearities can be neglected (or in case ϑ is close to 0 or to 90°). Figure 6.
Nondimensional natural frequencies (in the rotating frame) and decay rate for a beam with β = 0, γ = 0, δη = 0.5, ζ = 0.2, ψ = 0.8 and χη = 2 with different values of angle ϑ. Both the undamped and the damped cases are reported.

When angle ϑ = 0 the same results shown in Figure 5 are obtained (only the positive natural frequencies are reported here). No instability has been found. If ϑ = 90° the same results obtained above for the Jeffcott rotor are obtained: the figure is the same as Figure 3, except for the fact that here the natural frequencies are referred to the rotating frame, while in the former figure they were referred to an inertial frame and made nondimensional by dividing them by the largest natural frequency instead of the smallest.

There is an instability range due to asymmetry, which becomes smaller with increasing damping, and a second instability range due to rotating damping. In the intermediate cases the instability threshold shifts at higher values of the speed with decreasing angle ϑ , tending to infinity when ϑ → 0.

The instability thresholds are plotted as functions of ϑ in Figure 7, again neglecting the nonlinearities present in the static solution. The case considered above is characterized by a fairly high anisotropy, δη = 0.5, and even in the case of the Jeffcott rotor (ϑ = 90°) the instability range of the undamped system due to anisotropy is fairly large (from Ω*=δη=1/2 to Ω* = 1). The instability ranges both widen and shift toward higher frequencies with decreasing ϑ, and below ϑ ≈ 30° the threshold of instability is so high that is beyond any practical speed range. Figure 7.
Instability ranges for two beams with δη = 1 (symmetrical) and δη = 0.5 (asymmetrical) as functions of angle ϑ. Other data: β = 0, γ = 0, ζ = 0.2, ψ = 0.8 and χη = 2.

In the plot for δη = 1 the beam is symmetrical and no instability due to asymmetry should be present. This is true for the Jeffcott rotor, and actually above δη = 0.9 (or below δη = 1.1) no instability range could be found even for the undamped system. Damping further stabilized this kind of instability. But this field of instability appears again for lower values of ϑ : below 67° for the undamped system and 55° for the damped one an instability range of the same kind of that which was considered above a due to asymmetry is present even in the symmetrical system. Here a sort of asymmetry can be considered as due to angle ϑ itself.

sec.title: Beam moving under the action of the motor torques
sec.p: The equations of motion from (50) to (53) can be written in the state space as (82)[M*04×404×4I4×4] z'={f(z)+u[z1z2z3z4]T} where (83)z=[X·TXT]T

The mass matrix of this system is singular, as it could be easily expected owing to the concentration of all masses in the end mass of the beam. Equation (46) (or equation (82)) is not a set of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), but a set of mixed algebraic and differential equations (DAEs), even if the two kinds of equations are not separated. To separate them it is possible to resort to diagonalization procedures, to obtain a diagonal mass matrix with some (theoretically 2) elements on the main diagonal equal to zero. However, in the following parts of this article this will not be attempted, since there are integration algorithms able to perform the integration of a set of DAEs of this kind.

A further set of control equations linking the control input vector u to the state vector z and possibly its derivative or integral (in case of a PID control) must be added, following the selected control strategy.
All the equations above are strongly nonlinear and no linearization is in general possible. The only feasible solution approach is thus numerical integration in time.

To evaluate the influence of the flexibility of the beam, the equations of motion of a rigid beam are reported. These equations, involving the coordinates φ and ϑ only, are not written in nondimensional form, since the quantities used to make the equations nondimensional are strictly related with the beam flexibility, namely with the natural frequency ωζ in the xζ plane. They are still equation (46), but now (84)X=[ϕϑ]T, u=[M1*M2*]T (85)M=ml2[[γ+cos(ϑ)]2001] (86)f1=2ml2sin(ϑ)[cos(ϑ)+γ]ϑ·ϕ·-Cnl2[γ+cos(ϑ)]2ϕ· +ml[-gxsin(ϕ)+gycos(ϕ)][γ+cos(ϑ)] (87)f2=-ml2sin(ϑ)[cos(ϑ)+γ]ϕ·2-Cnl2ϑ·-mlgzcos(ϑ)+ -mlsin(ϑ)[gxcos(ϕ)+gysin(ϕ)]

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: Consider a rotating beam with rectangular cross section, 10 × 5 mm2 (the wider side along y axis) and 500 mm long. The beam, made in steel with E = 210 GPa, is attached on the rotation axis (r = 0) and is 500 mm long and carries an end mass m = 10 kg. The main nondimensional parameters are thus δη = 0.25, δx = 10,000 and γ = 0, while angle β = 0.
Study the stability at varying value of angle ϑ, taking into account that the allowable strength of the material is σa = 500 MPa.

The maximum nondimensional speed that can be reached, at which the allowable strength of the material is reached, can be obtained from equation (78). The instability conditions are plotted in Figure 8, on which also the maximum speed is reported. The light gray area is the instability range, the darker one covers the zone in which the stress is higher than the allowable stress. The dark grey areas are those in which both condition (instability and overstressing) are reached. The plot has both the nondimensional and the dimensional velocity scale. From Figure 8 it is clear that the instability conditions can be reached only if ϑ > 70°} . Below this value the beam shows a stable behavior in the whole allowable field. Figure 8.
Instability ranges of the system studied as Example 1 both with and without damping. The medium grey area denotes the conditions in which the material is stressed beyond the allowable conditions.

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: Consider a very flexible robot arm carrying an end load whose mass is much larger than that of the arm itself. The arm operates in space, so that gi*=0. Assume the following data: m = 100 kg, aluminium (E = 78.1 GPa, density 2700 kg/m3) beam, 5 m long with an annular cross section with inner and outer diameters of 100 mm and 90 mm respectively, and r = 500 mm. Assume that the only damping is the structural damping of the beam, with loss factor η = 0.05: by using the conventional simplified (constant) equivalent damping approach, it follows that ζ = η /2.

The nondimensional parameters are thus γ = 0.1, δη = 1, ζ = 0.025, χ = ψ = gi*=0 and the value of β is immaterial. The mass of the beam is just the 20% of the end mass, so the present model is justified, and the natural frequency of the nonrotating beam is ωn = 5.63 rad/s.

The beam performs a manoeuvre to reach a final position with φfin = 90° and ϑfin = 60° starting from a rest position with φ = ϑ = 0. The motors are controlled by an ideal PI controller with proportional and derivative gains Kp = 200 kNm/rad and Kd = 50 kNms/rad and no saturation is considered. The controller tries to follow a trajectory with constant acceleration for 5 s and then constant deceleration for a further 5 s, so that the whole manoeuvre is completed in 10 s. This implies an ideal acceleration ϕ··=±0.0628 rad/s2 and ϑ··=±0.0419 rad/s2.

The results of the numerical integration of the equations of motion is shown in Figure 9, where the time histories of the tip diplacements uy and uz, the angular displacements φ and ϑ and velocities ϕ· and ϑ· and the motor torques M1 and M2 are reported. Figure 9.
Time history of the elastic displacement of the tip, of angles ϕ and ϑ, of the angular velocities ϕ· and ϑ· and of the driving torques M1 and M2 during the manouver described.

The results related to the rigid beam are also reported: they are completely superimposed, except for the motor torques where the vibration of the flexible beam introduces oscillations of the torques that are obviously not present in the case of the rigid beam: this is due to the type of control that has been assumed, where the motors try to keep constant the acceleration of the beam, applying driving torques that compensate for the inertia torques due to the beam vibration. This is possible in practice owing to the low-frequency behavior of the system.

The time histories obtained through a simplified model in which no stiffening due to rotation is accounted for and all terms containing the product of two or more displacements and their derivatives are neglected. As it is possible to see from Figure 8(a), the differences are very small, and occur only at about 5 s, when the angular velocities reach their maximum values.

From the figure it is clear that the rotation dynamics is little affected by the vibration of the beam, but this is mostly due to the controller that succeeds in keeping the angular acceleration of the beam constant, in spite of the fact that the beam vibrates. The vibration dynamics is, on the contrary, much affected by the motion of the beam, that excites strong vibrations that tend to persist even after the manoeuvre has been completed. This is a well-known phenomenon, and is much affected by the way the torque is applied to the beam. It is known that moving the arm with a constant acceleration, applied abruptly (often referred to as a ‘bang-bang’ law), is the worst way of performing this manoeuvre and that a suitable application of the torque can strongly reduce the beam vibration and the time needed for the beam to reach a steady condition. These considerations are, however, beyond the scope of this article. Here what is interesting is to note that, even in a case where the motion is quick enough to excite strong vibration, the effect of the angular velocity on the stiffness of the beam, and then on its vibration, is almost negligible.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The dynamic behavior of a beam that rotates in the three-dimensional space has been studied. The beam is assumed to have no mass, and to be supplied of a point mass at its end: the model has thus three deformation degrees of freedom, plus two degrees of freedom related to rotation.

A general form of the equations of motion has been obtained, using the classical assumptions of the ‘Euler–Bernoulli’ beam, but releasing the small displacement assumptions so that the effect of the axial force on the lateral behavior can be considered.

A first set of results has been obtained by imposing the rotation angles and thus studying a 3-degrees of freedom system. Namely, the angular velocity about z axis, ϕ· and angle ϑ have both been assumed to be constant. In this condition, it has been shown that:

list-item.p: If ϑ = 90° the usual equations found in the literature for the asymmetric Jeffcott rotor have been obtained. Two instability ranges are found: the lowest lies between the two critical speeds, is due to asymmetry and is reduced by the presence of damping, both of the rotating and nonrotating type. High damping makes this instability range to disappear. The second instability range occurs at high speed, is due to rotating damping and moves to higher speed at increasing ratio between the nonrotating and rotating damping. It is well known that, if damping is of the viscous type, it always exists, even if it may be located at exceedingly high speeds.

If ϑ = 0 there is no instability range, and the natural frequencies of the system always increase with increasing speed. Even rotating damping does not cause the system to become unstable, since the Campbell diagram does not cross the ω = Ω line.

At intermediate values of angle ϑ the instability ranges moves at higher speed with decreasing ϑ. Two instability ranges exist, even if the cross section of the beam has an ellipse of elasticity that degenerates into a circle, since a sort of nonsymmetry is provided by angle ϑ.

The above considerations, however, do not take into consideration the fact that, except for the case where ϑ = 90° and γ = 0, the beam is loaded both by a bending moment and an axial force that increase with the square of the angular velocity. Particularly for values of ϑ between 10° and 80°, these stresses may be quite high, and they compel to limit the angular velocity. As shown in Example 1, in practical cases this limitation is much more severe than that due to intability, so that no instability range practically exists for angles ϑ below 60°–80°.

sec.p: If all degrees of freedom are accounted for, a control law that governs the angular motion can be introduced into the model. An example has shown that if the task of the beam is that of moving from one position to another, like in robot arms, the dynamic problems are much more due to the angular accelerations than to the angular velocity. The speed is usually low enough to be neglected and the system can be approximated using a model in which a stationary beam is loaded by the inertia forces due to the angular accelerations ϕ· and ϑ·.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
